ygData.msgSnippet: right - i mixed up my paragraphs there, that fitness is what i m currently using, with just agents trying to track the target. yeah, my thought was your second

right - i mixed up my paragraphs there, that fitness is what i'm currently 
using, with just agents trying to track the target.

yeah, my thought was your second suggestion, to max distance from It while 
not It, and to min distance to opponents while It - although about the 
second part i'm not sure whether to min distance to all opponents, or the 
closest opponent, or what.

i think i'll go read their paper and try to maintain my interest in this 
subject when someone else has already done it more thoroughly and 
completely ... there are so many cool ideas that i have that when i start 
looking i find someone has already done :)

cheers,
-KB-

On Fri, 14 May 2004, Derek James wrote:

> Here's that paper I believe you were talking about Kennon:
> 
> http://www.red3d.com/cwr/papers/1994/alife4.html
> 
> > fitness is the average
> > distance from the target over a certain number of time steps.
> 
> Wouldn't it make more sense for the fitness function to be a function
> of time spent as "it"?
> 
> Or if it were based on distance from competitors, wouldn't you want to
> maximize distance from opponents while not "it", and minimize distance
> from opponents when "it"?
> 
> Derek
